abstract.value: William Gropper was a cartoonist, painter, and muralist known for his contributions to Social Realism painting and his political cartoons in left wing publications in the early and middle of the 20th century. He worked as an illustrator for the <emph render="italic">New York Tribune</emph>, and later contributed to left wing publications including <emph render="italic">The Masses</emph>, <emph render="italic">The Liberator</emph>, <emph render="italic">The Revolutionary Age</emph>, and <emph render="italic">Morgen Freiheit</emph>. This collection consists of approximately 100 signed, undated political drawings by Gropper created approximately in the 1920s through the 1940s, the majority of which were for <emph render="italic">Morgen Freiheit</emph>. Subjects present in the drawings in this collection include May Day demonstrations, labor strikes and lockouts, working conditions, the American Labor Party (ALP), New York City electoral politics, opposition to fascism in Europe, and anti-communist activities, such as the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate the Educational System of the State of New York (also known as the Rapp-Coudert Committee).

p.value: Identification of item, date; William Gropper Drawings; TAM 788; box number; folder number or item identifier; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated by Craig Gropper in October 2018 and December 2019; the accession numbers associated with this donation are 2019.041 and 2019.148.

William Gropper (1897-1977) was a cartoonist, painter, and muralist known for his contributions to Social Realism painting and his political cartoons in left wing publications in the early and middle of the 20th century. Gropper was born in New York City to Jewish immigrants from Romania and Ukraine who worked in the garment industry. He worked as an illustrator for the <emph render="italic">New York Tribune</emph>, and later contributed to left wing publications including <emph render="italic">The Masses</emph>, <emph render="italic">The Liberator</emph>, and <emph render="italic">The Revolutionary Age</emph>. Gropper was also the staff cartoonist for <emph render="italic">Morgen Freiheit</emph>, a Yiddish publication affiliated with the Communist Party, USA. Gropper's drawings for these publications frequently portrayed workers with compassion and critiqued powerful politicians or business owners. He also created multiple murals as part of the Works Progress Administration (WPA). Although he prolifically contributed to communist publications, Gropper was not formally a member of the organization and declined specifying affiliations to political parties.

This collection consists of approximately 100 signed, undated political drawings by William Gropper created approximately in the 1920s through the 1940s. The majority of the drawings were created for publication in the New York City newspaper <emph render="italic">Morgen Freiheit</emph> (English title <emph render="italic">Morning Freedom</emph>), which was affiliated with the Communist Party, USA. Gropper's drawings include pencil notations on sizing, layout, and publication deadlines. Subjects present in the drawings in this collection include May Day demonstrations, labor strikes and lockouts, working conditions, the American Labor Party (ALP), New York City electoral politics, opposition to fascism in Europe, and anti-communist activities, such as the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate the Educational System of the State of New York (also known as the Rapp-Coudert Committee).

subject.value: Labor movement -- United States -- Pictorial works.
